etymology.description: 阳(yang; male) + 具(tool; organ) = male organ/genitals
etymology.interpretation: Literally the “yang/male apparatus,” combining the male principle 阳 with 具 ‘implement/organ.’ Used as a somewhat euphemistic or literary term for the penis, often contrasted with the more clinical 阴茎.
etymology.simplification: 陽 → 阳 by simplifying the right-side component 昜 to reduce strokes; 具 unchanged.

parts.english: yang; male; sunny/bright; south side of a mountain

examples.chinese: 医生在体检中会询问男性的阳具是否有不适(醫生在體檢中會詢問男性的陽具是否有不適)。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng zài tǐjiǎn zhōng huì xúnwèn nánxìng de yángjù shìfǒu yǒu búshì.
examples.english: During a physical exam, the doctor may ask if a male patient has any discomfort in his genitals.

examples.chinese: 这本医学教材使用“阳具”和“阴茎”两个词，但语气略有不同(這本醫學教材使用「陽具」和「陰莖」兩個詞，但語氣略有不同)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè běn yīxué jiàocái shǐyòng “yángjù” hé “yīnjīng” liǎng gè cí, dàn yǔqì lüè yǒu bùtóng.
examples.english: This medical textbook uses both “yangju” and “penis,” but the tone differs slightly.

examples.chinese: 在一些古代文献里，阳具被视为“阳”的象征(在一些古代文獻裡，陽具被視為「陽」的象徵)。
examples.pinyin: Zài yīxiē gǔdài wénxiàn lǐ, yángjù bèi shìwéi “yáng” de xiàngzhēng.
examples.english: In some ancient texts, the male organ is seen as a symbol of the yang principle.
